text:
Anyone willing to brag about a great employee onboarding experience at their company? :sunglasses:

I'm working on the post covering the employee onboarding topic and need some great examples! Tag me or shoot a DM if you have anything to share.

elements.text: Anyone willing to brag about a great employee onboarding experience at their company?
I'm working on the post covering the employee onboarding topic and need some great examples! Tag me or shoot a DM if you have anything to share.

text: I have a client who is having me write a piece on "employee poaching." Her employees brought up the topic, as they had heard "rumors" of developers/creatives getting poached by larger west coast firms. (they are a midwest firm). She said that many of these larger agencies are paying developers/creatives sometimes double their current salaries to do remote work from the Midwest or places with cheaper costs of living. What are our thoughts here? Has anyone seen examples of this?  While as a creative (who lives in a place with a low cost of living), I would like to work for a larger firm that paid me more - but where does that leave the smaller firms/small businesses? Am I part of the problem, or is the problem more than that?

elements.text: I have a client who is having me write a piece on "employee poaching." Her employees brought up the topic, as they had heard "rumors" of developers/creatives getting poached by larger west coast firms. (they are a midwest firm). She said that many of these larger agencies are paying developers/creatives sometimes double their current salaries to do remote work from the Midwest or places with cheaper costs of living. What are our thoughts here? Has anyone seen examples of this?  While as a creative (who lives in a place with a low cost of living), I would like to work for a larger firm that paid me more - but where does that leave the smaller firms/small businesses? Am I part of the problem, or is the problem more than that?

text:
I don't think you are part of the problem. I believe that money matters a lot. Being able to make money you want to make while working in a place you want to work is something that many people want.

I think that small businesses will have to rethink their approach to hiring to make up for this. If you can't offer money, what can you offer? Is it work/life balance? Is it your mission? Do you have an internal program to build employee skills? What sets you apart from someone who can pay double or triple? Money isn't everything to every person. It may become deprioritized as people become financially stable at larger companies or as people begin their careers. I know plenty of people who would rather work at a startup than a large organization.

I think that small businesses can weather the storm of employee poaching. They just need to think outside the box.

text: <@U01J85VRKF1> this is excellent. I think it would be a good idea to add in a section of "how to stay competitive" for those smaller agencies. But you're right - I've worked corporate before and it was absolutely the pits. I like to stick within the mid-level business range myself. I also wonder if age/experience also has something to do with it. I had a friend who just turned down a (pretty excellent job IMO), at Adobe because as she said "the pace/expectation was just too much, and I'm too old to be working 90 hours a week anymore."  I thought her reaction was interesting, and how maybe some of these "larger paying roles" also have around-the-clock expectations which can be, frankly, exhausting.

text:
I suspect companies that can go remote, will be expected to. Otherwise they'll face questions like, "Why aren't you remote?" Without an answer that puts employee wellbeing at its heart, I think they'll have a hard time.

Why work remote (locally) vs remote (at a distance)? My answer would be culture. I would personally prefer a smaller, less-paid position if it had great company culture. I'd better wake up and look forward to work, or I'll start looking elsewhere.

text: Hey <@U015XHF0RE0> - I recently started a new job and had a pretty great onboarding experience. Would be happy to talk with you about it if you're interested. :grin:
